etymology.definition: The study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed throughout history

etymon.definition: The original form of a word from which another word is derived

etymological.definition: Relating to the study of the origin and history of words

etymologist.definition: A person who studies the origins and historical development of words

logic.definition: Reasoning conducted or assessed according to strict principles of validity

logical.definition: Of or according to the rules of logic or formal argument

lexicon.definition: The vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge

dictionary.definition: A book or electronic resource that lists the words of a language and gives their meaning

vocabulary.definition: The body of words used in a particular language

word.definition: A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing

language.definition: The method of human communication, either spoken or written

linguist.definition: A person skilled in foreign languages or who studies linguistics

linguistics.definition: The scientific study of language and its structure

dialect.definition: A particular form of a language which is peculiar to a specific region or social group

vernacular.definition: The language or dialect spoken by the ordinary people in a particular country or region

proto-word.definition: A reconstructed ancestral word from which later words are derived

root.definition: The basic form of a word which cannot be further analyzed without loss of identity

morpheme.definition: The smallest grammatical unit in a language

stem.definition: The root or main part of a word to which inflections or formative elements are added

affix.definition: An addition to the base form or stem of a word to modify its meaning

prefix.definition: An element placed at the beginning of a word to adjust or qualify its meaning

suffix.definition: A morpheme added at the end of a word to form a derivative
